awd_titl_txt: Stable Organic Interfaces Having Unnatural Compositions: Nanoscale Control of Heterogeneity
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor T. Randall Lee of the University of Houston is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry to design and synthesize new organic chemical agents.  A major goal of the proposed research is to tune the chemical composition of thin organic coatings to afford surfaces with compositions that are not found in nature.  Given the unique compositions targeted, the coatings are likely to be extraordinarily non-adhesive and therefore useful for coating not only electronic devices (e.g., ultrathin cell phones, laptops, and flat-screen televisions), but also artificial implants (e.g., heart stents) and nanoparticles for medical applications (e.g., cancer therapy).  During the grant period, the PI seeks to broaden the participation of women and minorities through several educational/outreach activities, including the Welch Summer Scholars program, the UH STEM Center, the NSF-supported Houston Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (H-LSAMP) program, and visits to campus and research mentoring for local high school students.  

The proposed research seeks to design, synthesize, and utilize multidentate adsorbates for the generation of unnatural "conflicted" self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) on gold.  Three systems of current technological interest are emphasized: (1) the design and synthesis of multidentate adsorbates for fabricating highly stable thin-film coatings with uniquely controlled surface composition of chemical entities that are either phase incompatible or structurally dissimilar, for the purpose of generating homogeneously mixed heterogeneous "conflicted" interfaces; (2) the use of specifically fluorinated adsorbate molecules to generate nanoscale films having well-defined composition and structure, with an ultimate goal of defining the critical elements (e.g., minimum degree of fluorination) needed to construct organic interfaces with controlled hydrophobicity, anti-adhesiveness, and lubricity; and (3) the generation and study of thin-film architectures, including surface-grafted oligomeric films, in which the terminal functional groups mimic the backbones of industrially relevant polymers, with the goal of evaluating the interfacial properties and reactivity of well-defined polymer surfaces.  Advantages offered by the targeted multidentate adsorbates include films with markedly greater stability than those derived from n-alkanethiols, leading in part to advances in nanoscale lubrication, corrosion resistance, nanoparticle stabilization, and anti-adhesive coatings.  Furthermore, due to the restricted surface mobility of the multidentate adsorbates, mixed monolayers of these adsorbates functionalized with disparate chemical tailgroups offer "conflicted" organic nanoscale coatings with tailored chemical heterogeneity and controlled nanoscale roughness.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Technological advances are driving several industries toward the miniaturization of devices and materials, highlighting the important role that surfaces and interfaces play in the design of such materials. Of particular importance is the ability to design molecules that generate versatile, and stable films. Our research focuses on three systems of current technological interest: (1) the design and synthesis of multidentate adsorbates for fabrication of highly stable thin-film coatings with a uniquely controlled surface composition made up of chemical entities that are either phase incompatible or structurally dissimilar, for the purpose of generating heterogeneous "conflicted" interfaces; (2) the use of specifically fluorinated adsorbate molecules to generate nanoscale films having a well-defined composition and structure, with an ultimate goal of defining the critical elements (e.g., minimum degree of fluorination) needed to construct organic interfaces with controlled hydrophobicity, anti-adhesiveness, and lubricity; and (3) the exploration of thin-film architectures including surface-grafted oligomeric films, in which the terminal functional groups mimic the backbones of industrially relevant polymers, with the goal of evaluating the interfacial properties and reactivity of well-defined polymer surfaces. Prior to the work reported here, there were no examples detailing the science behind the construction of these types of unique surfaces. When taken as a whole, this research will lead to new and better materials for technologies ranging from ultra-inert coatings for biomedical implants to nanoscale corrosion-resistant films.

The Intellectual Merit of this project can be gleaned from the published work and public presentations over the award period, which are summarized herein: we designed and synthesized a wide variety of adsorbate molecules for the generation of stable, multi-component interfaces that expose either blended phase-incompatible chemical functionalities, charged termini, reactive functionalities, or chemical groups found along the backbones of commercially available polymers. Importantly, advantages offered by multidentate adsorbate films besides having markedly greater stability than those derived from n-alkanethiols include advances in boundary lubrication, corrosion resistance, nanoparticle stabilization, and nanopatterning via soft lithography. The results of this research were disseminated in the form of 37 international peer-reviewed publications, 34 invited talks, and 37 oral/poster presentations at various conferences. 

With regard to Broader Impacts during the award period, this project led to the research experiences of two postdoctoral fellows, twelve graduate students, three undergraduate students, and two high school students, many of whom hold underrepresented status (eight women and seven minorities; three of the undergraduate and four graduate students are described by both categories). In addition, five graduate students who worked on this project were granted their Ph.D. degree and one graduate student obtained her M.S. degree after successfully defending their dissertations and thesis, respectively. During the award period, the PI supported and promoted science education at two inner city schools in transition (Milby High School and Mickey Leland College Preparatory Academy for Young Men) as their campuses were being rebuilt, providing laboratory supplies and support for their chemistry programs as well as sponsoring (prior to the COVID pandemic "Day of Discovery" visits of the students to the campus of the University of Houston. Moreover, working with a STEM education team in the College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics at the University of Houston, my research group and I prepared a video for high school students that described the practical relevance of our NSF-supported research. A link to the video is provided here: https://uh.edu/nsm/teachhouston/summer-camps/stem-interactive/lessons/week-2-fri/

 


Last Modified: 01/07/2022
Modified by: T. Randall Lee
